Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I glance at the clock on my laptop, heart pounding. The product team’s brainstorming session is starting in five minutes. It’s technically optional, but I know how these things go—if I’m not there, my input on the new feature design will be missing, and I’ll be out of the loop. My team expects me to collaborate, to help shape the direction of our next release. But right now, I’m standing in a cramped polling station, clutching my ID, listening as the election official explains that my registration doesn’t match. If I want my vote to count, I have to fill out a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes. I nod, but my mind races. If I stay, I’ll miss the session and maybe let my team down. If I leave, I’ll lose my chance to vote. Both roles demand something of me, and I feel the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. My hands tremble as I stare at the form, torn between my duty as a developer and my right as a voter, knowing I can’t satisfy both.
